lines.text: Instead of the glorification of cowardly gangsters, we need the glorification of policemen who do their duty and give their lives in public protection. If the police had the vigilant, universal backing of public opinion in their communities, if they had the implacable support of the prosecuting authorities and the courts - I am convinced that our police would stamp out the excessive crime - which has disgraced some of our great cities - President Herbert Hoover.
Say that's mighty white of you guys.

[Ed steps between Daisy and her front door]
And don't kick me in the shin, or I'll smack you right in the face!
All right, copper!
How'd you come to think that one up?
Aw, you've got Headquarters written all over yuh!
Smart girl, huh?
Yeah, and I never got past the eighth grade.
Well, maybe you're bright enough to answer a few questions.
Sure, if you don't ask 'em in Yiddish!
[She pushes past him and goes into the door. Then suggestively]
Can you come in?
I'm right behind yuh.
I know how to make those lice talk.
I hate Belmonte and that crowd because they're behind everything in this town that's rotten. I mean to wipe 'em out if it takes hot lead.
I didn't like his ways.
[Laying down on a bed seductively]
I don't mind taking orders, but there's one decision that's always up to me.
Come on, sit up like a lady! I know that trick!
Oh, unintentional, mister.
[Lying in a laguorously sensual position]
Say, do you think I'm so dumb as to pull a gag like that?
You might. You're built for it!

[Ed grabs her arm tightly]
Say! That hurts a little bit.
And you don't like to be hurt, do you?
Oh, I don't know.
[Suggestively]
Kinda fun sometimes if it's done in the right spirit.

[Pushes her away]
Get the beer!

[Trying to discourage one of Belmonte's gun molls in the bedroom]
Listen, I'm an old man. I left my youth in the capitals of Europe.

[Seductively]
You know, it's a funny thing. You drink beer to make you cool - and it just makes yuh hot.
[She tugs on and flaps the low neck cleavage part of her dress]
I can't stand it. I gotta do something about it.
[She seductively walks away]

[after a passionate kiss]
I never thought I'd have a yen for a copper. Are you gonna' try and reform me, huh?
What for?
[They kiss passionately again]

[Watching the sergeant's solitaire game]
Hey, you're cheatin'! You've got a black queen on a black king!
What are you kickin' about? They don't seem to mind.

[while eating a sandwich, washed down with a bottle of milk, a plainclothes cop or reporter refers to a man who has been hanged - at least two days ago]
That's the way you gotta do with ducks. They're too gamey at first.
Well what else can you do? What do you expect me to do with gunmen, dope peddlers, and sneak thieves? Kiss 'em on the forehead or slap 'em on the wrist?
But chief I forgot to tell you about...

Yes you forgot to tell me about hitting an officer over the head. You forgot to tell me about shooting a little girl down in the gutter. You forgot to tell me about killing one of the finest white men that ever lived!

[enters jail cell full of yelling prisoners who suddenly go quiet]
Well, sounds like the inside of a bird store. Lot of fine brave boys aren't you? Come on, why don't you keep it up? Teacher's lookin' at you. That why? It'd be different if you were hidin' behind an alley door wouldn't it? It'd be different if you had that shot of hop handy so you could pump yourself full of enough guts to shoot somebody in the back . Take away your guns and your hop and you're nothing but crawling yellow maggots.
Hey, I wanna' talk to you. Heard about Belmonte last night, didn't you?
Yeah, but I can't get all steamed up about it. Dopey and his mob had it coming to them.
What kind of talk is that?
English, teacher, English. Shouldn't break our hearts because three or four heels get half-soled.
Well, it's just too ridiculous, that's all. Fitz is nothing but a tough, uncouth Irishman. He's liable to make things very embarrassing for you.
A good politician never gets embarrassed, Bert. That's something *you* should have learned.

[Addressing the assembled policeman, upon his being appointed the new Chief of Police]
We're going to start with a clean slate, see? I don't know a thing about any of you. Good or bad, efficient or inefficient. I'm not upsetting any apple cart. Every man keeps the job he's got now until he proves to me he's worth a better one or he has no right on the force at all. I'm not fighting you and you're not fighting me. We're going to fight together. Now this town has become about as rotten as an open grave. Only some of you have got so used to it you don't have to hold your noses anymore. Well, we're going to clean it up, understand? We're going to knock over every speakeasy, hook shop, wheel joint and gin mill from South Canal to North Haven. We're going to keep pulling in every monkey until they get so tired of it they'll all want to lie in the tanks or leave town. Leave the country - not the town, but the country! Each one of you is going to handle your own precinct in your own way. You know more about conditions there than anybody else. What I want is results! If I don't get results there's going to be a shake-up like the inside of a cement mixer. I'll get results if I have to put a patrolman at the head of the vice squad and precinct captains back to teaching rookies drill. All right now, go out and get to work. You'll get official confirmation on all orders before the day's up.

[the assembled policeman start to applaud loudly, but Jim waves them to be silent]
No, no... never mind those open hands. Close them up into fists, and use them!
Are you married?
Nope.
I thought all cops were married.
I'll stick to variety.
Ooh, a girl in every precinct, huh?

[drunkenly]
Yeah, somethin' like that.
If you keep your shades down, you wouldn't be bothered. Put yourself in his position.
I tell you, Joel, you'll change your mind. You just had a tough experience. That's all.
Aw, baloney. I learned about women from her. Say, I wouldn't look at another dame if she was Zigfield's best!

[On the radio]
Calling car number 47, number 4 - 7, a nude woman at the corner of Elm and Berry.
Oh, let's go! Hurry, we might lose her!

[On the radio]
A nude woman at the corner of Elm and Berry. All other cars stay away.
Say, those don't look like pancakes!
Oh-oh, Dad will you read the Funnies to me before I go?
Well, I guess you'll have to - start moving right away. You don't mind, do you dear?
Mama goes where Papa goes.
You're swell, Mary. Kinda makes a guy want to go on.

Listen, I may know some of the big shots in this racket, see, but that's all. When I get a hunch they're going to start arguing, I step next door. I got my own game when I play it and it doesn't include helping somebody to make somebody else to stop breathing. I don't want any murder jobs hung on me.
I once got a shock from the electric toaster and I never quite forgot about it.
Wait a minute. Let's talk in comfort. I got some real swell beer on the ice.
Sure, and a glass with some knock-out drops for me.
Oh, you gotta stop going to the movies.
How did you happen to notice me?
I don't know. You're not exactly a collar ad, but - say, what's your name?
Fitzpatrick.
Not Fightin' Fitz's brother?
That's right.
Now I can understand - why you were so hard boiled at first.

[Opens and looks out her window]
Hey, if you want an eyeful, come over here. Look!
Heh?
[Ed walks over, with a beer, and sees a belly dancer in the next building]
Oh! Boy! She certainly does know how to wiggle, doesn't she!
That girl doesn't know how to dance.
No?
No!
[Walks to the middle of her apartment and seductively starts to dance - Ed watches and suddenly embraces and kisses her]
He'd make a good dick, if he ever puts his mind to it!
What are you tryin' to make - a sissy out of me?
Say, where's the cripple?
Right here!
Hi Jim.
Kid... how are ya?
Daddy's shot. Isn't it swell!
Why, Mickey, how do you say such a thing!
Well, it is swell, isn't it?
Well, you big baboon, they couldn't keep you off the front page if they put you in a straight jacket. Been kinda insulting you, haven't they?
Mary's been reading me a lot of hot air.
Aw, it's not a lot of hot air. It's hysteria! Your names being flung around headquarters like a pass to a speakeasy.
Where have you been keeping yourself lately? Busy?
Yeah, I've been real busy these days - junkie investigation.

[to his brother Ed]
Pay a little more attention to your job, that's all. What do you do with your money anyway? You haven't got any expense living with us. You still running around with a lot of dames? Hey now, get wise to yourself and grow up.
You've got to get another pint, darling.
A quart, honey, a quart.
You sure know me, baby!

[Opening a beer]
Oh, boy, did I get you all wet?
I've always been all wet, honey.
I wish somebody would invent one of these bottles that didn't always fizz.
I'll take care of that the first thing in the morning.
[Toasting]
Down the boobie hatch.
It's pretty hot tonight.
You're telling me!
No, I mean the orchestra. It's not as good as that one at Purple Lodge. Remember? Say, let's go up there this weekend. We never go any place anymore, except come to this dump!
Oh, listen, baby, it's you and me all alone and nobody around. That's a real part of the act, isn't it?
I know, but, look, Ed, suppose you like corn meal mush too. It gets a little monotonous if you didn't add cream and sugar once in awhile.
I just like the mush.
[Kiss]
Bring that champagne over, will ya?
Very well, Mr. Belmonte.
We'll have us a real party, eh?
Fizz water! You hear that! Say, I haven't brushed my teeth in bubbles for ages!

[Noticing his handfull of bills]
That's mighty pretty wallpaper, Sam. Business must be good.
Yeah, I got a corner in the grapefruit market.
How about those kegs of California orange juice?
You know it's funny about those grapefruits. They're being trucked in over the Huntington Turnpike; but, it's getting pretty bumpy out there and they're somewhat liable to get spoiled.

[Reaching for the champagne]
Give me that buttermilk. I'm gonna get stewed.
I've just given Ed the Bartman assignment, he needs bucking up!
I'm sick of everything.

[Lays down beside him]
You're not sick of me, baby.
Sometimes I wish I could be; but, I can't. Oh, you beautiful shot of hot!
[Passionate kiss]
So, you're going to put on a false mustache and get your man, huh?
Nah, they signed me up as a nurse maid to a truckload of dough.
Oh, some bank takin' the vegetables outta the cellar and they're scared of rabbits, is that it?
Yeah, they put me on loan - my opportunity or something.

[Walks in on a girl flirting with Ed]
Back to the bush leagues for you sister! And shut the door from the outside!
I'm going away in a couple of days, Ed.
I'll be right here when you come back.
Nope. I'm laming for good!
Hey, what do you mean?
Oh, I'm just sick and fed up with this whole town. I guess I always gotta be on the move, that's all.
Fighting Fitz tries to send up his own brother and Sam Belmonte gets him off. I guess that'll show dem whose the boss of this town!
